intro: Haploclathra paniculata var. verticillata, commonly known as the clustered false indigo, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and showy, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers, which bloom in spring, are usually blue to purple in color and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The variety verticillata is distinguished by its clustered inflorescence, which gives it its common name.
